Name: Agriculture present
Description: Agriculture (horticulture) present (i.e., domesticated food plants cultivated)

Name: Agriculture and domestic animals are primary subsistence
Description: Agriculture and/or domesticated animals provide the major part of subsistence (about 75% or more)

Name: Agricultural plots repeatedly cultivated
Description: Agricultural plots repeatedly cultivated except for periods of fallow (if they occur)

Name: Improved techniques of planting
Description: Improved techniques of planting (e.g., mounds, planting in rows, breaking of clods, plowing, fertilization)

Name: Soil-working tools
Description: Soil-working tools other than the digging stick (e.g., hoe, spade, rake, foot plow)

Name: Harvesting tools
Description: Harvesting tools other than a simple beating stick used in reaping or threshing domesticated plants (e.g., flail, sickle, rice header, winnowing tray)

Name: Animal-drawn plow
Description: Animal-drawn plow

Name: Fertilization of land
Description: Fertilization of land with material other than wood ashes (e.g., animal manure, night soil, green manure, compost, fresh soil or mud)

Name: Fences built to protect crops
Description: Fences built around fields or gardens to protect crops

Name: Major male contribution to agriculture
Description: Men do as much or more of the agricultural work as women (beyond clearing)

Name: Increasing agricultural land through drainage
Description: Drainage employed to increase the area of available agricultural land

Name: Irrigation of agricultural land
Description: Irrigation of agricultural land

Name: Permanent dams or dikes
Description: Permanent dams or dikes to impound water for irrigation, drinking, etc.

Name: Terracing
Description: Terracing (including the erection of barriers to reduce soil slippage)

Name: Agricultural land reverted
Description: Agricultural land reverts to kinship group (e.g., lineage, sib), chief or tribe, king or state, as personal property or for reassignment when owner abandons the land or dies without heirs

Name: Agricultural land reapportioned
Description: Most of the agricultural land systematically reapportioned from time to time by the village, chief, tribe, or state to insure equitable distribution and/or a high degree of cultivation, rather than for services rendered

Name: Measures to promote or maintain agricultural production
Description: Chief, king, or other official(s) takes measures to promote or maintain agricultural production (e.g., requires land to be worked efficiently and punishes failure to do so)

Name: Planting and harvesting times determined by specialists
Description: Political or religious officials or other specialists determine the time of planting and harvesting

Name: State or church provides farmers with equipment
Description: State or church provides farmers with seed or tools for agricultural purposes

Name: State surveying of agricultural land
Description: State surveying of agricultural land

Name: Regular food surplus accumulation
Description: Surplus of food regularly accumulated over and above the annual subsistence needs of the food producers, and not consumed by them

Name: Agricultural estates
Description: Agricultural estates which regularly produce a sizable surplus of food for sale to urban centers

Name: Cash crops
Description: Cash crops raised entirely or largely for sale rather than for domestic consumption

Name: Government granaries
Description: Granaries erected by the government and food distributed from them by a government official

Name: Domesticated animals serve as a source of food
Description: Domesticated animals serve as a source of food (exclude the eating during famines or other unusual occasions of domesticated animals not normally used as food)

Name: Domesticated animals used for packing
Description: Domesticated animals used for packing

Name: Domesticated animals used for traction
Description: Domesticated animals used for traction

Name: Domesticated animals used for riding
Description: Domesticated animals used for riding

Name: Domesticated animals kept for wool or hair
Description: Domesticated animals kept for wool or hair

Name: Selective breeding of domesticated animals
Description: Selective breeding of domesticated animals

Name: Specialized herdsmen or dairymen
Description: Specialized herdsmen or dairymen

Name: Fisheries or fish ponds
Description: Fisheries or fish ponds stocked and maintained to provide a regular supply of fish for food

Name: Settlements occupied for more than 10 years
Description: Settlements occupied for more than 10 years, on the average (but not necessarily all year around but at least 40 percent of the year)

Name: Settlements occupied for at least 50 years
Description: Settlements occupied for at least 50 years (but not necessarily all year around but at least 40 percent of the year)

Name: Settlements arranged in regular patterns
Description: Settlement(s) arranged in regular pattern(s), (e.g., long house, houses in rows or streets, houses built around a square or plaza)

Name: Communities of 100 or more
Description: Permanent communities (settled or nomadic) of about 100 or more members

Name: Communities of 500 or more
Description: Permanent communities (settled or nomadic) of about 500 or more members

Name: Towns of 2,000 or more
Description: Towns: nucleated settlements of 2,000 or more residents

Name: Two or more towns
Description: Two or more towns

Name: City of 10,000 or more
Description: City: administrative and commercial population center of at least 10,000 residents

Name: Two or more cities
Description: Two or more cities

Name: City of 100,000 or more
Description: City of 100,000 or more residents

Name: Planned cities
Description: Planned cities

Name: Paved streets
Description: Paved streets

Name: Paved sidewalks
Description: Paved sidewalks

Name: Paved plaza
Description: Paved plaza (exclude patios surrounded by house walls or exclusive to individual houses)

Name: Civic or ceremonial structures
Description: Civic or ceremonial structures (including menÂ’s house) not ordinarily used as dwellings by family units (excluding structures built for specific occasions and later abandoned, dismantled, or destroyed)

Name: Permanent cemeteries
Description: Permanent cemeteries, where the graves of the interred are marked

Name: Stone monuments commemorating persons or events
Description: Stone monuments or stelae (excluding cairns of unworked stones) to mark or commemorate important persons or events (e.g., megaliths, obelisks, triumphal arches, pyramids)

Name: Grandstands, theathers, amphitheaters, or stadiums
Description: Grandstands, theathers, amphitheaters, or stadiums where spectators can witness contests or performances

Name: Formal or landscape gardens
Description: Formal or landscape gardens

Name: Ornamental fountains
Description: Ornamental fountains

Name: Aqueducts or conduits
Description: Aqueducts or conduits of stone or brick to supply water for domestic use

Name: Running water piped into buildings
Description: Running water piped into dwellings or public buildings

Name: Rain-catching or water-holding cisterns
Description: Cisterns: rain-catching or water-holding basins artificially lined with stone or other hard or impervious material (excluding clay)

Name: Baths of stone, brick, or tile
Description: Baths of stone, brick, or tile

Name: Drains
Description: Drains: lined channels, covered or uncovered, or pipes used to carry off rain or bath water

Name: Sewers
Description: Sewers: lined and covered channels or pipes, primarily for carrying away human waste

Name: Apartment houses
Description: Apartment houses: multi-storied dwellings in which rooms are customarily rented to tenants

Name: Permanent fortifications
Description: Permanent fortifications (including palisades around settlements, blockhouses, citadels, and fortified boundaries, but excluding structures whose primary purpose is not defensive, e.g., compounds, fortifications around dwellings which are normally occupied by only one or a few families)

Name: Stone or brick fortification walls
Description: Walls of stone, brick, adobe, or beaten earth (including earthworks) used in fortification

Name: Frontiers fortified with stone walls
Description: Frontiers fortified with stone walls

Name: Moats
Description: Moats (excluding dry ditches but including diverted rivers) used to protect settlements or fortifications

Name: Taverns
Description: Taverns, inns, or eating houses providing food, drink, and/or lodging

Name: Brothels
Description: Brothels

Name: Fire brigade
Description: Fire brigade

Name: Well-maintained roads connecting settlements
Description: Broad and well-maintained roads connecting settlements

Name: Network of paved roads connecting settlements
Description: Network of paved roads connecting settlements

Name: Bridges or causeways
Description: Bridges or causeways (excluding log spans, vine ropes, and simple pole frameworks)

Name: Way stations or resthouses
Description: Way stations or resthouses, not necessarily staffed, which provide lodging for travelers

Name: Rectangular ground plan for dwellings
Description: Rectangular ground plan for dwellings

Name: Houses occupied for at least 10 years
Description: Substantial houses which are lived in for at least 10 years without being permanently abandoned, dismantled, or rebuilt

Name: House interior divided by walls or partitions
Description: Interior space of houses permanently divided by means of walls or partitions (include lofts)

Name: Multi-room dwellings
Description: Dwellings divided into three or more walled-off and separate rooms, with some degree of functional differentiation between them

Name: Multi-family dwellings
Description: Dwellings which customarily house four or more family units

Name: Multi-storied structures
Description: Multi-storied structures (not meant to include high storage platforms or lofts which do not form a complete story)

Name: Parts of dwellings extensively painted or carved
Description: Walls, ceiling, roof, or other part of dwellings or other structures extensively painted or carved

Name: Cut stone masonry
Description: Cut stone masonry

Name: Stone or brick bases for civic or ceremonial structures
Description: Cut stone or brick substructures (e. g., platforms, truncated pyramids) used as bases for civic or ceremonial structures

Name: Dwellings of stone or brick
Description: Dwellings (including walls) constructed of cut stone or fired brick

Name: Civic or ceremonial buildings of stone or brick
Description: Civic or ceremonial buildings constructed of cut stone or fired brick

Name: Monumental architecture of stone or brick
Description: Monumental architecture of stone or brick (e.g., pyramids, palaces, temples, fortresses, amphitheaters, but excluding solid platforms)

Name: Quarrying of stone for construction
Description: Quarrying of stone for construction (rather than merely dressing loose stones)

Name: Megalithic construction
Description: Megalithic construction using blocks of stone too heavy to be moved without mechanical devices such as rollers, sledges, ramps, or pulleys

Name: Stone coursing
Description: Stone coursing (blocks of cut stone laid in successive horizontal layers)

Name: Rubble used between walls in stone or brick construction
Description: Rubble or some other fill used between walls in stone or brick construction

Name: Fired brick used in construction
Description: Fired brick used in construction

Name: Walls of beaten earth or adobe
Description: Walls of beaten earth or adobe

Name: True mortar used in construction
Description: True mortar (i.e., a plastic substance with a chemical bonding action) used in construction

Name: Facing of stone or brick walls or columns
Description: Facing of stone or brick walls or columns with plaster, alabaster, tile, etc.

Name: Roof of tile, brick, dressed stone, planks, etc.
Description: Roof of tile, brick, dressed stone, planks, etc. (i.e., not bark, mud, thatching, or similar material)

Name: House floors made of stone, brick, tile, wood etc.
Description: House floors made of stone, brick, tile, flagstone, or wood (including palm and bamboo)

Name: Stone lintels
Description: Stone lintels

Name: Arches of stone or brick
Description: Arches of stone or brick (corbeled or keystone)

Name: True arch
Description: True (keystone) arch

Name: Stone or brick pillars or columns used structurally
Description: Stone or brick pillars or columns used structurally

Name: Stone or brick stairways
Description: Stone or brick stairways (of cut blocks, or carved into living rock)

Name: Buttresses used to strengthen stone or brick walls
Description: Buttresses used to strengthen stone or brick walls

Name: Ornamental carving of stone architectural features
Description: Ornamental carving of stone columns, walls, lintels, or other architectural features of stone

Name: Architectural features cut into living rock
Description: Architectural features (e.g., tombs, stairways) cut into living rock

Name: Fortresses built of stone or brick
Description: Fortresses built of stone or brick (including walled cities and citadels, where people take refuge in time of war)

Name: Elaborations in fortified walls
Description: Elaborations in fortified walls (including, e.g., towers, salients, merlons, but excluding loopholes)

Name: Professional carpenters or woodworkers
Description: Professional (full-time) carpenters or woodworkers (excluding canoemakers and thatchers)

Name: Professional stone masons or bricklayers
Description: Professional (full-time) stone masons or bricklayers

Name: Professional architects or engineers
Description: Professional (full-time) architects or engineers

Name: Landed property
Description: Landed property: individual or familial ownership rights over improved land (e.g., cultivated plots, house sites) continue to be exercised, even if land ceases to be occupied or worked

Name: Boundary markers to indicate private property limits
Description: Boundary markers (excluding growing crop plants but including hedges) set up in order to indicate the limits of a piece of private property

Name: Agricultural land commonly bought and sold
Description: Agricultural land commonly bought and sold

Name: Economic speculation in commodities
Description: Economic speculation in land, foodstuffs, or other commodities a common practice

Name: Inscription of land or other forms of property
Description: Inscription of land or other forms of property (registry of deeds)

Name: Rental of land or dwellings
Description: Rental of land or dwellings by landlords to tenants as a system of tenure

Name: Share-cropping
Description: Share-cropping: a system of land tenure in which the tenant (who is not a serf) pays the landlord a specific proportion or amount of the crop as rent

Name: Leasing of land or dwellings
Description: Leasing of land or dwellings: a formal agreement (not merely observance of custom) in which a tenantÂ’s right of occupancy is guaranteed for a specified period

Name: Serfs
Description: Serfs: tenants and their descendants legally bound to land which they farm for the benefit of private persons or corporate groups (e.g., feudal lords, temples, monasteries)

Name: Private or government control over natural resources
Description: Private ownership (not ownership by a sib or a local group) or government control exercised over scarce or limited natural resources (e.g., clay pits, clam beds, salt, water holes, mineral deposits, grove of wild fruit trees) rather than free access to them

Name: Distinctive marks used to indicate property ownership
Description: Seals, brands, or other distinctive marks used to indicate ownership of manufactured property

Name: Wealth differences among society members
Description: Marked differences in wealth (e.g., real property, livestock, precious metals, slaves; but excluding wives, ceremonial bundles) among members of the society (other than the difference between the principal political leader or religious specialist and everyone else)

Name: Feasts or gift-giving ceremonies showcasing wealth
Description: Feasts or gift-giving ceremonies in which much wealth is displayed or consumed, including those for state purposes

Name: Recorded inventories of property owned
Description: Recorded inventories of property owned (e.g., with pebbles, knotted cords, notched sticks, clay tablets, ledgers)

Name: Most individual property inherited
Description: Most individual (not family) property owned and in the possession of a person at the time of his death (exclude property lent out and still outstanding) transmitted by inheritance rather than being buried, destroyed, or otherwise disposed of at the death of the owner

Name: Testamentary disposition of property
Description: Testamentary disposition of property, by a written will, through a formal executor, or orally in the presence of a witness (excluding incorporeal property)

Name: Craft specialization
Description: Craft specialization: some craft(s) which only a limited number of persons in the society practice (excluding the making of religious or ceremonial objects by shamans or priests, or chiefs)

Name: Craft production for economic exchange
Description: A significant amount of craft production primarily for economic exchange rather than for personal consumption

Name: Full-time craft specialists
Description: Full-time craft specialists (e.g., brewer, lapidary, tailor, baker, tanner)

Name: Service specialization
Description: Service specialization: some services which only a limited number of persons in the society provide (excluding religious specialists and curers, but including clans and other groups that perform specialized services)

Name: Full-time service specialists
Description: Full-time service specialists other than religious practitioners (e.g., tattooer, barber, accountant, lawyer, physician)

Name: Professional barbers or hairdressers
Description: Professional barbers or hairdressers

Name: Professional porters or bearers
Description: Professional porters or bearers

Name: Full-time food production specialists
Description: Processing or preparation of food by full-time specialists (e.g., millers, butchers, cooks, bakers) other than household servants or slaves

Name: Professional brewers or wine makers
Description: Professional brewers or wine makers

Name: Full-time clothing or shoes makers
Description: Clothing or shoes manufactured by full-time specialists

Name: Medium of exchange used in trade
Description: Medium of exchange, which is frequently used in trade for a variety of commodities

Name: Currency
Description: Currency: a medium valued primarily for its use in economic exchanges rather than as an ornamental or consumable good, and which may be exchanged freely for any goods or commodities which are traded

Name: Economic exchange in currency or money
Description: A significant amount of economic exchange carried out by means of currency or money

Name: Metallic currency valued according to weight
Description: Metallic currency valued according to weight (including coins)

Name: Two or more metals used as currency
Description: Two or more metals of different monetary value used as currency

Name: Coined money
Description: Coined money

Name: Coins of different denominations
Description: Coins of different denominations

Name: Animals or foodstuffs lent out at interest
Description: Animals, seed crops, or foodstuffs lent out at interest

Name: Money or goods lent out at interest
Description: Money or goods (not including animals or foodstuffs) lent out at interest

Name: Professional moneylenders
Description: Professional moneylenders

Name: Banks
Description: Banks, which pay interest on deposits and make loans

Name: Pledging of movable property as debt security
Description: Pledging of items of movable property as security on a debt

Name: Pledging of oneself or family member as debt security
Description: Pledging of oneself or members of oneÂ’s family as security on a debt

Name: Mortgage
Description: Mortgage: a legal instrument offering land or houses as security to guarantee the repayment of a loan

Name: Insurance
Description: Insurance: protection against calamities (e.g., fire, theft, loss of merchandise at sea) offered by an underwriter for a premium

Name: Trade between communities
Description: Trade between communities

Name: Economically important trade between communities or regions
Description: Economically important trade carried out between communities or regions (including that conducted through itinerant merchants)

Name: Economically important trade in finished goods between communities
Description: Economically important trade in which finished goods (excluding food) are traded to other communities or societies (including exchanges conducted through itinerant merchants)

Name: Full-time specialists in trade
Description: Full-time specialist(s) in trade

Name: Trading outposts
Description: Trading outposts maintained outside the territory of the society

Name: Markets
Description: Markets, in which a variety of goods are traded

Name: Daily and permanent markets
Description: Daily and permanent markets

Name: Specialized urban markets
Description: Specialized market(s) within a town or city (e.g., fish market, cattle market, textile market, flower market)

Name: Itinerant merchants or specialized traders
Description: Itinerant merchants or specialized traders who are members of the society itself (rather than foreigners), and who remain such even if they trade outside the society

Name: Sedentary merchants
Description: Sedentary merchants who operate fixed commercial establishments outside the market area

Name: Wholesale merchants
Description: Wholesale merchants

Name: Professional merchants undertake large-scale trading expeditions
Description: Professional merchants undertake large-scale trading expeditions

Name: Merchants form a significant segment of the society
Description: Merchants form a significant segment of the society

Name: Merchant class with particular rights or restrictions
Description: Merchants constitute a class, with prescribed advantages (e.g., exemption from military service or corvÃ©e labor) and/or disabilities (e.g., exclusion from holding office, subjection to discriminatory taxation)

Name: Legally enforceable economic contracts
Description: Contracts: economic agreements legally enforceable by a higher authority

Name: Economic transactions formally witnessed or notarized
Description: Economic transactions formally witnessed or notarized

Name: Commercial agreements negotiated between states
Description: Commercial agreements negotiated between states

Name: Commerical transactions authenticated with seals, signatures, or marks
Description: Seals, signatures, or individual marks used to authenticate commercial transactions

Name: Warehouses for privately-owned merchandise
Description: Commercial warehouses used to store privately-owned merchandise

Name: Written documents used for large-scale goods shipments
Description: Bills of lading or other written documents used in large-scale shipments of goods

Name: Long-term commercial records kept
Description: Long-term commercial records kept

Name: Companies
Description: Companies: business enterprises including two or more persons who are organized to carry out commercial or industrial operations

Name: Corporations
Description: Corporations: companies, chartered by the state, the members of which have limited liability

Name: Labor mobilized by compensation
Description: Labor mobilized by the offer of compensation (rather than by a kinship obligation), e.g., food and drink, payment in kind or money, salary

Name: Hire of individuals for unskilled manual labor
Description: Individuals commonly hired to perform unskilled manual labor

Name: Wage labor
Description: Wage labor, for which payment is made at definite rates and intervals

Name: Enforced mobilization of labor for public projects
Description: Enforced mobilization of labor for community, tribal, or state projects (excluding military conscription)

Name: CorvÃ©e
Description: CorvÃ©e (draft labor exacted by a supra-community authority or agency)

Name: Institutional employment of artisans and laborers
Description: Artisans and laborers attached to or employed on a regular basis (rather than under the corvÃ©e) by political or religious institutions (tribe or state, temple or church)

Name: Labor overseers
Description: Overseers, who superintend the labor of slaves or other workers (other than majordomos on private estates)

Name: Factories
Description: Factories: enterprises in which workers, under unified supervision, produce goods by performing differentiated tasks (including temple workshops)

Name: Manufacturer trademarks
Description: Trademarks placed on articles to identify the maker or manufacturer (e.g., potterÂ’s mark, swordsmithÂ’s signature, mint marks)

Name: Class of freemen artisans selling their products or services
Description: Class of artisans who are freemen and who sell their products or services

Name: Neighborhoods of specialized artisans within towns or cities
Description: Neighborhoods of specialized artisans within towns or cities

Name: Certain industries concentrated in particular villages, towns, or cities
Description: Certain industries concentrated in particular villages, towns, or cities

Name: Guilds of craft or service specialists
Description: Guilds (i.e., cooperative associations) of craft or service specialists, including labor unions

Name: Guilds of merchants or bankers
Description: Guilds of merchants or bankers

Name: Taxation in kind
Description: Taxation in kind (including produce from land farmed for the state, but excluding required contributions to community projects or ceremonies)

Name: Taxation in currency
Description: Taxation in currency

Name: Official tax, tribute, or customs collectors
Description: Official tax, tribute, or customs collectors (excluding local chiefs)

Name: Regular taxes
Description: Collection of taxes in kind or currency on a regular schedule and at fixed rates

Name: Special taxes
Description: Special taxes, in addition to regular taxes, levied for special needs (e.g., war expenses, public works, royal marriages; but excluding primarily religious taxes)

Name: Tax obligations commutable into state service
Description: Tax obligations commutable into service to the state or its representative

Name: Assessors appraising property for tax calculation
Description: Assessors (as distinct from tax collectors) who appraise land or other property, and determine the amount of taxes to be paid

Name: Taxes on land
Description: Taxes assessed on land

Name: Taxes on movable property
Description: Taxes assessed on movable property (including crops and livestock)

Name: Taxes on commerce
Description: Taxes on commerce (e.g., sales taxes, taxes on goods brought to market, ground rents on places in market)

Name: Taxes on luxury goods
Description: Taxes on the manufacture, sale, or consumption of luxury goods

Name: Inheritance taxes
Description: Inheritance taxes

Name: Duties on imported goods
Description: Duties on goods imported, or transported across internal boundaries

Name: Tolls
Description: Tolls collected for the use of roads, bridges, or ferries

Name: Produce from private lands for the ruler or state
Description: Produce of certain privately-worked lands set aside for the chief, king, tribe, or state (exclufing chief's land worked by the people at large for his support)

Name: Superintendent of royal or state herds, lands, or forests
Description: Superintendent who supervises the maintenance of royal or state herds, lands, or forests

Name: The extent of landholdings limited by law or decree
Description: The extent of landholdings limited by law or decree

Name: State-regulated rent on private property
Description: State fixes rent or rent ceilings on privately owned lands or dwellings

Name: Government operates industries or exploits resources directly
Description: Government operates industries or exploits resources directly (e.g., weaving, armoring, goldsmithing; mines, salt deposits)

Name: Government derives revenue from industries and resources indirectly
Description: Government derives revenue from industries and resources indirectly (e.g., licenses salt production, wine making, ironworking, mining)

Name: Government registration or licensing of specialists or merchants
Description: Government registration or licensing of craft specialists, service specialists, or merchants for purposes of taxation or control

Name: State contracts private enterprises for certain functions or goods
Description: State lets out contracts to private enterprises for the performance of certain functions (e.g., public works, tax collection) or the supply of certain goods

Name: State sells or auctions public property
Description: State sells or auctions public property (e.g., public lands, confiscated property, captured war booty) to raise revenue

Name: Government trades commodities on the open market
Description: Government buys or sells commodities on the open market

Name: State obtains loans from private or foreign sources
Description: State obtains loans from private sources or from other states

Name: Governmental supervision or regulation of commerce
Description: Governmental supervision or regulation of commerce (e.g., inspecting weights and measures, maintaining order in markets, settling commercial disputes, enforcing payment of debts, fixing price levels)

Name: Government inspection or regulation of places of entertainment
Description: Government inspection, licensing, or regulation of places of entertainment (e.g., taverns, gambling houses, brothels)

Name: State-directed trade
Description: State-directed trade (i.e., trade carried on by agents of the state with other societies)

Name: Wage levels of certain occupations fixed by law
Description: Wage levels of certain occupations fixed by law

Name: Interest rates fixed by law and usury punishable
Description: Interest rates fixed by law and usury punishable

Name: Distraint of property for debt default or tax nonpayment
Description: Distraint of property (by government officials, not private seizure) for default of debts or nonpayment of taxes

Name: Government distributes food in times of shortage or famine
Description: Government relieves conditions of food shortage or famine by distributing or selling foodstuffs

Name: Public or church support of the destitute
Description: Public, government, or church support (as against support by kinsmen or tribesmen only) of the destitute (e.g., widows, orphans, aged, or infirm), excluding becoming wards or servants of the chief or king by indigent person

Name: Social segments above family
Description: Social (rather than territorial) segments above the level of the extended family or household (e.g., lineages, sibs, moieties, marriage classes, social classes, castes, age grades, menÂ’s clubs, secret societies, warrior societies, ceremonial teams, craft guilds)

Name: Two or more social segments
Description: Two or more different types of social segments

Name: Unilineal kin groups beyond families
Description: Unilineal kin groups (segments) beyond extended families (including royal or chiefly lineages)

Name: Genealogies for at least five generations
Description: Genealogies traced back reliably for at least five generations

Name: Voluntary associations
Description: Voluntary associations, permanent and corporate, based on principles other than kinship or age

Name: Blood brotherhood
Description: Blood brotherhood or other special friendships solemnized by ceremonies

Name: Occupational classes, castes, or descent groups
Description: Occupational classes, castes, or descent groups (excluding slaves, but including clans with specific duties)

Name: Bride price, bride service, or gift exchange
Description: Marriage formalized by bride price, bride service, or gift exchange between the bride and groom or their families

Name: Dowry
Description: Dowry (as distinguished from the contribution of the bride or her family in gift exchange)

Name: Marriage celebrated with a feast
Description: Marriage celebrated with a feast

Name: Marriages performed by priests or state officials
Description: Marriages performed or registered by priests or officials of the state (not including the mere blessing of the couple by a priest)

Name: Significant social status differences
Description: Well-defined and significant differences in social status (other than the difference between the principal political leader or shaman and everyone else, or differences based on age or sex)

Name: Wealth accumulation brings prestige or influence
Description: The accumulation of wealth in movable property or land, even without its redistribution, brings considerable prestige or influence

Name: Social stratification into distinct classes
Description: Stratification of the society into distinct social classes (excluding status distinctions based only on age or sex, and the ranking of clans or subclans)

Name: Social stratification into at least three classes
Description: Stratification of the society into at least three distinct social classes

Name: Differences of rank within the upper classes
Description: Differences of rank within the upper class(es) other than that based on political or religious office or sex

Name: Class distinctions in legal liability for offenses
Description: Class distinctions in legal liability for offenses (i.e., members of the various social classes have different rights under the law)

Name: Ornaments, clothing or other marks distinguishing social classes
Description: Special ornaments, differences in clothing, or other marks, which distinguish members of one class from the rest of the society

Name: Insignia of noble or high rank
Description: Insignia of noble or high rank (e.g, ear plugs, special hairdos, coats of arms) meant primarily to indicate status rather than being largely ornamental

Name: Sumptuary laws
Description: Sumptuary laws concerning dress, adornment, or other manifestations of wealth and serving to maintain class distinctions

Name: Some society members have superior residences
Description: Some members of the society (other than the political leader) have categorically superior residences

Name: Some society members own more land
Description: Some members of the society (other than the political leader) own significantly more land than others

Name: Majordomos
Description: Majordomos supervise staffs of private households or estates (other than that of the political leader)

Name: Some society members have numerous wives or concubines
Description: Some members of the society (other than the political leader) have numerous wives or concubines (at least 8 or 10)

Name: Some society members have servants or retainers
Description: Some members of the society (other than the political leader) have permanent servants or retainers (other than slaves)

Name: Persons of high rank have special privileges
Description: Persons of high rank (other than the political leader) have special privileges (e.g., exemption from taxation or corvÃ©e, right to hold political office, right to remain seated in the kingÂ’s presence) excluding privileges relating to dress and ornament

Name: Competitive sports or spectacles staged by the upper classes
Description: Competitive sports or spectacles staged by the political leader or members of the upper classes

Name: Hunting primarily an upper class pastime
Description: Hunting primarily a pastime of the chief, king, or upper classes

Name: Codes of social conduct distinguishing class or status
Description: Elaborate code of social conduct serves to distinguish between social classes or individuals of different social positions

Name: Class differences in disposal of the dead
Description: Status (excluding age and sex) class, or caste differences in disposal of the dead (based on social rather than religious status; exclude shamans and priests)

Name: Some society members buried with wealth or animal sacrifices
Description: Some members of the society (other than the political leader) buried with large amounts of wealth, or have a considerable number of animals sacrificed at their death

Name: Some society members buried with wives, retainers or slaves
Description: Some members of the society (other than the political leader) buried with or accompanied in death by wives, concubines, retainers, or slaves

Name: Some society members elaborately buried
Description: Some members of the society (other than the political leader) buried in elaborate tombs or graves (e.g., burial mounds, cist graves, thatched buildings)

Name: Extrasocietal slavery
Description: War captives or persons bought outside the society kept as slaves without subsequently being liberated, killed, or granted equal status with native-born members of the society

Name: Intrasocietal slavery
Description: Debtors or criminals made slaves, or other freeborn members of the society (including wives and children) sold into slavery

Name: Slaves branded, tonsured, or otherwise identified
Description: Slaves branded, tonsured, or otherwise identified

Name: Slaves as personal servants
Description: Some slaves kept as personal servants and not used in economically productive activities (including cooking)

Name: Slaves economically significant
Description: Slaves as a class economically significant, i.e., they add to the economy more than they consume (produce food, make goods, or yield a product in significant amounts, rather than merely doing odd work)

Name: Slaves bought and sold within the society
Description: Slaves bought and sold within the society (excluding the selling into slavery of freeborn members of the society)

Name: Slave markets
Description: Slave markets

Name: Hereditary slavery
Description: Hereditary slavery

Name: Manumission of slaves common
Description: Manumission of slaves common

Name: Supra-community political units
Description: Communities (or camps) continuously grouped (year-round) into larger political units which recognize some central authority

Name: Supra-provincial political organization
Description: Districts or provinces, each comprising several villages or communities, are permanently grouped into a larger political unit

Name: Three or more levels of territorial administration
Description: Three or more levels of territorial administration above the community (e.g., 1. district, 2. province, 3. quarter, 4. kingdom)

Name: State
Description: State: permanent organization of a number of supra-community units (districts, tribes, or provinces) into a single political unit under centralized control, involving at least (a) some power to collect revenue, (b) the power to conscript men for work or war, (c) some centralized judicial authority, and (d) the power to formulate and execute policy

Name: Population of 100,000 or above
Description: Population of the state 100,000 or above

Name: Population of 1,000,000 or above
Description: Population of the state 1,000,000 or above

Name: Citizenship
Description: Citizenship: citizens have certain rights under the law which non-citizens do not have

Name: Capital city or town
Description: State or tribe has capital city, town, or village

Name: Municipal quarters
Description: Towns or cities divided into quarters or wards for civil or judicial purposes

Name: State redistricts or moves populations
Description: State endeavors to maintain administrative units of approximately equal size at each of several levels by redistricting or by the movement of populations

Name: Permission to move between administrative units
Description: Government permission required to move from one administrative unit to another

Name: Colonists
Description: Colonists sent to settle in conquered or newly-opened territory

Name: Young persons sent to capital for training, service or as hostages
Description: Young persons sent to capital for training or royal service or as hostages

Name: Headman, chief, king, or council of elders
Description: A generally recognized agent or agency of the society (e.g., headman, chief, king, council of elders) makes decisions or policy affecting the society as a whole

Name: Powerful political leaders
Description: Political leader(s) has the power, by threat or exercise of active sanctions, to make individuals comply with his decisions (e.g., can assign tasks, draft labor, impose taxes, command military service)

Name: Political leader exercises judicial power
Description: Political leader(s) exercises judicial power (decides guilt and decrees punishment, or settles cases appealed to him; does not merely mediate)

Name: Political leader exercises supreme judicial authority
Description: Political leader(s) exercises supreme judicial authority, e.g., has the power to reverse decisions of inferior judges or courts in civil or criminal cases

Name: Leadership transmitted through royal line
Description: Chiefly or kingly line through which political leadership is customarily transmitted

Name: Heir apparent undergoes training for future office
Description: Heir apparent undergoes rigorous or intensive training or education as preparation for his future office, including, e.g. serving as governor of a province

Name: Property qualifications required for public office
Description: Property qualifications required for appointment or formal election to public office

Name: Secondary political leaders
Description: Secondary political leader(s) who have authority over segments of the society (e.g., sub-chiefs, house chiefs, clan chiefs, governors)

Name: Advisory council for political leader
Description: Formally constituted council (permanent or ad hoc) or official who advises, deliberates with, or controls the political leader

Name: Non-territorial advisors or administrative civil officials
Description: Non-territorial advisors or administrative civil officials: functionaries who advise or act at the direction of the political leader, but who are not personal servants or retainers (e.g., talking chiefs)

Name: Officials overseeing government-controlled activities
Description: Specialized officials in charge of one or more activities or enterprises controlled or supervised by the government

Name: Hierarchy of non-territorial administrative officials
Description: Hierarchy of non-territorial administrative officials (excluding palace hierarchy)

Name: Secondary political officials may appoint their subordinates
Description: Secondary political officials may appoint their subordinates

Name: Provincial administrative centers
Description: Provincial or district administrative centers where officials appointed by the state (other than local chiefs) collect taxes or maintain order

Name: Municipal governments
Description: Towns or cities within a larger political unit have municipal governments

Name: Secretariat administering laws or decrees
Description: Secretariat, in charge of drafting, promulgating, and circulating laws or royal decrees

Name: State accountant or treasurer
Description: Accountant or treasurer who keeps track of the wealth accumulated by the chief, king, or state

Name: Inspectors, censors, or secret agents
Description: Inspectors, censors, or secret agents who examine records or investigate the functioning of officials, popular discontent, etc.

Name: Census taken
Description: Census taken (including simple enumerations or head counts)

Name: Organized messenger or courier system
Description: Organized messenger or courier system which links together most of the societyÂ’s territory

Name: Ministries
Description: Ministries: government departments headed by ministers and having full-time staffs of officials and clerks

Name: Ministry of revenue or finance
Description: Ministry of revenue or finance

Name: Ministry of public works
Description: Ministry of public works

Name: Ministry of justice
Description: Ministry of justice

Name: Ministry of religious affairs, rites, or ceremonials
Description: Ministry of religious affairs, rites, or ceremonials

Name: Ministry of foreign affairs
Description: Ministry of foreign affairs

Name: Ministry of war
Description: Ministry of war

Name: Prime minister
Description: Prime minister: principal administrative official below the ruler who initiates or executes policy

Name: Council of ministers advising the ruler
Description: Council of ministers forming a regular advisory body to the ruler

Name: Authentication devices for official actions
Description: Devices used to confirm or authenticate official orders, decrees, actions, and transactions (e.g., seals, signatures, rings, or other symbols)

Name: Auditing of government financial accounts
Description: Auditing procedures to check for errors or embezzlement in government financial accounts

Name: Government budget
Description: Budget: a comprehensive and itemized estimate of anticipated revenues and expenditures, periodically prepared by government officials

Name: Annals of state affairs
Description: Annals of state affairs regularly kept by official historian(s)

Name: State archives
Description: Archives in which official records and state papers are kept

Name: State officials paid a fixed salary
Description: State officials paid a fixed salary

Name: Officials' salaries paid in currency
Description: Officials' salaries paid, at least in part, in currency rather than in kind

Name: Codified regulations for administrative structure
Description: Codified regulations minutely govern the constitution and operation of the administrative structure

Name: Political leader is a full-time specialist
Description: Political leader does not ordinarily engage in subsistence

Name: Political leader abstains from low-status activities
Description: Political leader may not engage in certain common economic activities, which are considered to be beneath his status

Name: Political leader entertains on a lavish scale
Description: Political leader entertains on a lavish scale

Name: Political leader bestows land, slaves, rank
Description: Political leader bestows land, slaves, wealth, women, or noble rank for services rendered

Name: Political leader appoints officials
Description: Political leader appoints and deposes subordinate political officials

Name: Political leader promulgates laws
Description: Political leader promulgates laws, issues decrees, or makes proclamations to the populace (not just orders that are obeyed)

Name: Political leader grants audiences
Description: Political leader grants formal audiences to hear grievances or petitions (exclude appeal in legal cases)

Name: Political leader travels around the kingdom
Description: Political leader makes regular visits to various parts of the kingdom to examine conditions, hear cases, collect taxes, awe his subjects, etc.

Name: Political leader travels with a retinue
Description: Political leader travels with a retinue

Name: Political leader controls religious institutions
Description: Political leader exercises considerable control over the activities of temples or the church (e.g., performs investiture of priests, endows temples)

Name: Political leader performs essential societal rituals
Description: Political leader performs rituals considered essential for the welfare of the society, and which only he can perform

Name: Installation ceremony for political leader
Description: Special ceremony for installation or investiture of new political leader (e.g., oath of office, coronation)

Name: Political leader has special symbols of office
Description: Political leader has special symbols of office or authority (e.g., throne, crown, scepter, seal, robes)

Name: Deference to political leader
Description: Displays of special deference to political leader (e.g., carrying in a litter, averting the eyes, bowing)

Name: Officials or sub-chiefs swear allegiance to the leader
Description: Officials, vassals, sub-chiefs, or courtiers swear allegiance to the chief, king, or state

Name: Political leader addressed by honorific titles
Description: Political leader addressed or referred to by various honorific titles

Name: Lese majesty severely punished
Description: Lese majesty Â— an offense against the dignity, person, or property of the ruler Â— severely punished

Name: (Semi)divine ruler
Description: Ruler is considered divine, semi-divine, or sacred, or traces his descent from a god

Name: Political leader buried with wealth
Description: Political leader buried with large amounts of wealth

Name: Political leader buried with wives or slaves
Description: Wives, concubines, retainers, or slaves of political leader buried with him or otherwise killed at the time of his death

Name: Political leader elaborately buried
Description: Political leader buried in an elaborate tomb or grave (e.g., burial mound, cist grave, thatched building, pyramid)

Name: Special treatment to preserve leaderÂ’s corpse
Description: Special treatment (e.g., desiccation, embalming) to preserve the political leaderÂ’s corpse or part thereof (not just the bones)

Name: Deceased political leader reverenced
Description: Deceased former political leader especially reverenced (e.g., his spirit invoked or propitiated, monuments erected to his memory)

Name: Ruler receives food and goods as gifts, tribute or taxes
Description: Chief or king receives large amounts of food and/or other goods as gifts, tribute, taxes, or fines

Name: Special residence for political leader
Description: Political leader lives in a special residence or compound categorically superior to any other residence

Name: Royal estates
Description: Royal estates, residences, or preserves outside the capital which are the property of the ruler

Name: Full-time retainers for political leader
Description: Political leader has full-time personal attendants or retainers

Name: Royal household maintained by a steward and staff
Description: Royal or chiefly household maintained by a steward and staff

Name: Court
Description: Court, a body of officials, members of the upper classes, retainers, entertainers, etc., surrounding the chief or king

Name: Ruler has significantly more wives or concubines
Description: Chief or king has significantly more wives or concubines than anyone else

Name: Ruler has a harem
Description: Chief or king has a harem (a special residence(s) supervised by a responsible official(s), e.g., a eunuch)

Name: Ruler has a bodyguard
Description: Bodyguard to protect the rulerÂ’s person

Name: Private tutors for children of nobles
Description: Private tutors retained at court to instruct prince(s) and/or children of nobles

Name: Political leader has storehouse or treasury
Description: Political leader has storehouse or treasury (for hard goods or valuables, rather than for food)

Name: Formal treaties between societies
Description: Formal treaties (recorded or witnessed and sworn) concluded between societies to establish alliances, to settle disputes, or to end wars

Name: Ambassadors
Description: Ambassador(s): diplomatic representative acting in regular relations with a foreign government

Name: Diplomatic missions
Description: Diplomatic missions by government officials carried out for specific purposes

Name: Passports, visas, or tallies
Description: Passports, visas, or tallies to control the entry or exit of persons, native or foreign

Name: Superordinate tribe or state
Description: Superordinate tribe or state which receives tribute, labor, soldiers, or other recognition of obligation from subordinate or vassal tribe(s) or state(s)

Name: Resident officials overseeing native rulers of subordinate states
Description: Resident political officials who oversee native rulers of feudatory or tributary states

Name: Composition
Description: Composition: redress of death or bodily injury by payment of an indemnity to the victim or his relatives (with or without a formal judicial proceeding)

Name: Ordeals or oaths to establish guilt or settle disputes
Description: Ordeals or oaths to establish guilt or innocence or to settle disputes prescribed or enforced (exclude torture applied to extract a confession)

Name: Mediation used to settle inter-community disputes
Description: Mediation or formal legal procedure customarily used to settle at least one type of dispute within the political unit

Name: Land disputes settled by political or judicial authority
Description: Disputes over land settled by political or judicial authority, rather than only by mediation or fighting

Name: Judicial process
Description: Judicial process, in which an individual or limited group (e.g., council of elders, tribal chief, court of law) considers evidence and renders judgment in a dispute, or of an accused person, on behalf of the society

Name: Court trials
Description: Court trials, held under specialized judges or magistrates who hear testimony and weigh evidence, interpret the law or customary law, and render a decision in civil or criminal cases

Name: Judicial system of higher and lower courts
Description: Judicial system of higher and lower courts, cases being referred to one or the other according to their nature, with decisions of lower courts perhaps appealable to higher courts

Name: Specialized courts
Description: Specialized courts (e.g., commercial courts, military courts, ecclesiastical courts, divorce courts)

Name: Legal counsel
Description: Legal counsel: specialized advocates or lawyers who interpret the law or act for clients in legal cases

Name: Oaths or affirmations of truthful testimony
Description: Oaths or affirmations of truthful testimony required of witnesses in legal trials

Name: Oaths of compurgation accepted as evidence of innocence
Description: Oaths of compurgation accepted as evidence of innocence at legal trials

Name: Perjury or false testimony punishable by law
Description: Perjury or false testimony in court legal cases punishable by law

Name: Judges
Description: Judges: officials whose sole function it is to apply the law and render decisions in civil or criminal cases

Name: Police
Description: Police: specialized individual or force charged with keeping the peace, enforcement of norms, or the apprehension and detention of offenders

Name: Specialized public executioner
Description: Specialized public executioner

Name: Law
Description: Law: a body of explicitly formulated secular norms, interpreted, applied, and enforced by a constituted authority

Name: Recurrent decrees of laws
Description: Laws recurrently decreed by a ruler or enacted by a legislative body

Name: Code of laws
Description: Code of laws (explicit and recorded) which covers social, political, and/or economic relations

Name: Offenses against persons punishable by law
Description: Offenses against persons (e.g., sorcery Â— if actually practiced, assault, maiming, rape, murder) punishable under law or custom by formal means

Name: Offenses against property punishable by law
Description: Offenses against property (e.g., theft, arson, willful or inadvertent destruction) subject to indemnification or punishment under law or custom by formal means

Name: Obstruction of justice punishable under law
Description: Obstruction of justice (e.g., harboring of criminals, refusing to give evidence) punishable under law

Name: Laws governing marriage, abortion, or adoption
Description: Laws governing marriage, divorce, abortion, infanticide, or adoption

Name: Laws governing inheritance
Description: Laws governing inheritance

Name: Laziness, malingering, or vagrancy punishable by law
Description: Laziness, malingering, or vagrancy punishable by law

Name: Libel, slander, or malicious lying punishable by law
Description: Libel, slander, or malicious lying punishable by law

Name: Laws regulating borrowing and lending
Description: Laws regulating borrowing and lending

Name: Building codes
Description: Building codes: laws regulating house construction (e.g., prescribing building materials, limiting number of stories)

Name: Sacrilege severely punished
Description: Sacrilege Â— irreverence or disrespect toward a sacred person, place, custom, or object Â— severely punished

Name: Religious law enforced by political officials
Description: Religious law enforced by political officials

Name: Statute of limitations
Description: Statute of limitations specifying the time within which offenders must be brought to trial to be punishable

Name: Offenses punished by a designated agent rather than by the offended party
Description: Most offenses regularly punished by a designated or permanent agent of the society rather than by the offended parties themselves

Name: Crimes punishable by public authorities only
Description: Crimes legally punishable by public authorities only; private action illegal

Name: Offenses punished by fines
Description: Certain offenses punished by fines (in currency or in kind) paid to the lineage, sib or village, tribe or state, of which part may go to the offended party (including penalty feasts)

Name: Offenses punished by confiscation of property
Description: Certain offenses punished by confiscation of property, of which part may go to the offended party

Name: Political authority retains fines or confiscated property
Description: Fines collected or property confiscated by political authority and not shared with the offended party (unless he is the political leader)

Name: Corporal punishment
Description: Corporal punishment (including mutilation, shaving off hair) meted out for certain offenses by an authorized agent of the society (other than the offended party or his kin unless he is the political leader)

Name: Incarceration of convicted offenders
Description: Incarceration of convicted offenders (in shackles, stocks, pens, cages, or prisons)

Name: Offenses punished by slavery or hard labor
Description: Certain offenses punished by slavery or by terms at hard labor

Name: Death penalty
Description: Death penalty decreed by custom or after judicial procedure for certain crimes, and exacted openly by someone acting with the explicit approval of the society

Name: Commutation of certain sentences upon payment
Description: Commutation of sentences for certain crimes may be granted upon payment of a fixed amount

Name: Political leader sometimes pardons convicted offenders
Description: Political leader sometimes pardons convicted offenders

Name: General amnesties granted on special occasions
Description: General amnesties granted on special occasions

Name: Violation of secular law incurs punishment by gods and secular punishment
Description: Violation of secular legal norms automatically incurs punishment by gods during the individualÂ’s lifetime, as well as secular punishment by a formally designated agent of the society

Name: Warfare for reasons beyond personal conflicts or preemptive defense
Description: Warfare initiated for considerations other than (or in addition to) the avenging of insults, personal injury, murder, witchcraft, the stealing of women, trespass, or forestalling an enemy attack

Name: Economic reasons for warfare
Description: Economic considerations (e.g., territorial acquisition, the capture of booty, the taking of slaves) important in the initiation of warfare

Name: Religious reasons for warfare
Description: Warfare initiated in order to impose religious dogma or to make religious observances (e.g., human sacrifice)

Name: Formal warning or declaration of war
Description: Formal warning, challenges, or declaration of war, including the displaying of symbols, customarily given

Name: War leaders
Description: Recognized war leader(s) (other than a political leader) who regularly leads the men of the society against the enemy (e.g., war chief, general)

Name: Professional military commanders
Description: Professional military commanders (e.g., generals) who regularly lead the army in time of war

Name: Professional middle-level military officials
Description: Professional middle-level military officials (e.g., centurions, lieutenants, captains)

Name: Specially trained warriors
Description: Body of specially trained or highly skilled warriors (as distinct from the rest of the fighting men)

Name: Standing army
Description: Standing army, organized around a core of professional soldiers, and continuously maintained

Name: Militia
Description: Militia: a semimilitary organization with officers who keep its units in readiness to quell uprisings or repel invasions

Name: Military conscription
Description: Military conscription (those disinclined to fight either coerced into doing so, allowed to commute, or else subject to punishment)

Name: Military or corvÃ©e obligations fulfilled through substitutes or payments
Description: Substitutes may be hired or commutation paid to fulfill military or corvÃ©e obligations

Name: Troops receive fixed pay
Description: Troops receive fixed pay (over and above, or instead of, a share of the booty)

Name: Mercenaries
Description: Mercenaries (i.e., paid foreign troops) used in warfare

Name: Soldiers take oath of allegiance
Description: Soldiers or officers take oath of allegiance

Name: Fighting force divided into subunits
Description: Fighting force customarily divided into subunits

Name: Army organized into military units
Description: Army organized into groups of units which are successively more inclusive (e.g., platoons, companies, regiments, divisions)

Name: Organized war preparation drills and exercises
Description: Organized drills or exercises carried out to prepare for war

Name: Differentiated military units
Description: Differentiated military units (e.g., spearmen, bowmen, slingers, cavalry)

Name: Cavalry
Description: Cavalry

Name: Military engineers
Description: Military engineers

Name: Baggage trains used to transport the armyÂ’s supplies
Description: Baggage trains used to transport the armyÂ’s supplies

Name: Pitched battles
Description: Pitched battles, involving considerable hand-to-hand fighting, initiated, in which the objective is to destroy or drive off the enemy fighting force, or capture (rather than merely raid) enemy settlements

Name: Fighters begin battle in formation
Description: Fighters begin battle in formation (including arrangement in a straight line)

Name: Soldiers fight as compact units
Description: Soldiers fight closely aligned or as compact units, rather than as separate individuals

Name: Formal rules governing military conducts
Description: Formal rules governing conduct of soldiers and officers in war

Name: Government arsenals or armories
Description: Arsenals or armories where government stockpiles of weapons are maintained

Name: Cutting or thrusting weapons used in warfare
Description: Cutting or thrusting weapons used in warfare

Name: Defensive body armor
Description: Defensive body armor (exclude shields and helmets)

Name: Metal armor used in warfare
Description: Metal armor used in warfare

Name: Chariots used in warfare
Description: Chariots used in warfare

Name: Military emblems and banners
Description: Emblems, banners, or special objects which serve to identify military units, or act as rallying points, are carried into battle

Name: Musical instruments used for battle signals
Description: Drums, horns, trumpets, etc., used to signal commands in battle or to encourage troops (excluding the use of these instruments merely to frighten the enemy)

Name: Espionage
Description: Espionage, by special agents who gather strategic information in foreign territory by hiding their purpose and/or identity but not their persons

Name: Sieges laid to enemy fortifications
Description: Sieges laid to enemy fortifications strong enough to resist immediate assault

Name: Permanently garrisoned forts
Description: Permanently garrisoned forts (excluding observation posts, walled towns and cities)

Name: Battering rams
Description: Battering rams

Name: Assault ladders or towers used in sieges
Description: Assault ladders or towers used in sieges

Name: Siege ramps
Description: Siege ramps

Name: Catapult-type devices used as siege engines
Description: Catapult-type devices used as siege engines

Name: Body trophies
Description: Body trophies (e.g., heads, scalps, hands) taken in war or from sacrificed prisoners

Name: Military booty
Description: Considerable booty taken during successful military campaigns

Name: Adult male war captives
Description: Adult males frequently taken captive in warfare

Name: Cannibalism of war captives
Description: Cannibalism of war captives

Name: War captives regularly sacrificed to gods
Description: War captives regularly sacrificed to god(s)

Name: War captives kept for ransom or held as hostages
Description: War captives kept for ransom or held as hostages

Name: Special ornaments for brave or wounded warriors
Description: Special ornaments, insignia, or appellations awarded for prowess or wounds received in battle

Name: Rewards for outstanding warriors
Description: Outstanding warriors rewarded with gifts of property, women, or slaves, or appointment to official positions

Name: Nobility attainable through war exploits
Description: Nobility or distinctly high social status attainable through war exploits

Name: Penalty for cowardice, desertion, or insurrection
Description: Death, confiscation of property, or other severe punishment may be penalty for cowardice in battle, desertion, or insurrection

Name: Formal ceremonies to conclude inter-societal hostilities
Description: Formal ceremonies (including the making of treaties) to conclude hostilities with other societies

Name: Military prowess exhibited in parades or reviews
Description: Military parades or reviews in which military skill and prowess are exhibited (excluding celebrations held for returning warriors)

Name: Territory of vanquished enemy annexed
Description: Territory of vanquished enemy annexed

Name: Vanquished enemies subjugated and controlled
Description: Peoples of vanquished enemy subjugated and held under effective control

Name: Defeated political leaders pledge allegiance to conquerors
Description: Defeated political leader(s) or his relative(s) retained in authority over his territory on pledge of allegiance to conquerors

Name: Indemnities exacted from defeated enemies
Description: Indemnities or reparations (as distinct from tribute) exacted from defeated enemies

Name: Permanent settlements built in conquered territory
Description: Permanent settlements built in conquered territory

Name: Supernatural beings intervening for supplicants
Description: Supernatural being(s) who currently intervenes for the benefit of suppliants

Name: Ancestral spirits propitiated and invoked
Description: Ancestral spirits propitiated and invoked

Name: Gods
Description: God(s): specifically personified supernatural being(s) (not impersonal force) who is not particular to locations or to kinship segments (exclude, e.g., ancestral, guardian, and other personal spirits), to whom prayers are directed and who intervenes for the benefit of the society or its members

Name: Sun god
Description: Sun god worshipped (i.e., propitiated and invoked)

Name: God of war
Description: God of war (not necessarily connected exclusively with war) worshipped

Name: Lawgiver god
Description: Lawgiver god, who on more than one occasion has enunciated extensive rules for governing human conduct, worshipped

Name: Patron gods or saints
Description: Patron gods or saints (not including guardian spirits), who afford protection to groups of individuals engaged in particular occupations or activities (e.g., god of merchants, god of hunters, god of travelers, god of blacksmiths, god of war)

Name: Pantheon of gods
Description: Pantheon of gods worshipped (propitiated and invoked); (applies only to differentiated gods who actively control spheres of life or nature, e.g., rain god, war god, fire god, fertility goddess, love goddess)

Name: Paramount god in the pantheon
Description: One god in the pantheon of differentiated gods worshipped as paramount

Name: Life and death affects the afterlife
Description: Manner of living or dying affects the status or condition of the soul after death

Name: Offerings
Description: Offerings (including libations and sacrifices)

Name: Libations
Description: Libations: the ritual pouring, sprinkling, or drinking of a liquid

Name: Animal sacrifices
Description: Animal sacrifices directed to supernatural beings to placate them or gain their favor

Name: Human sacrifice
Description: Human sacrifice directed to supernatural beings to placate them or gain their favor

Name: Private worship of supernatural beings
Description: Private worship of supernatural beings through personally owned (rather than societally maintained) idols, altars, or shrines

Name: Priests perform private ceremonies for payment
Description: Private ceremonies or sacrifices performed by priests (not shamans or medicine men) on behalf of individuals for payment

Name: Priests conduct sacrifices on behalf of the society
Description: Priests conduct sacrifices on behalf of the society, or a significant segment thereof, to ward off calamities, solicit benefits, or offer thanks

Name: Rites of passage performed by priests
Description: Rites of passage performed by priests

Name: Rites to promote farming success
Description: Rites to promote fertility of the soil, to bring rain, or to celebrate the harvest performed seasonally (rather than merely when the crop is in danger)

Name: Thank offerings to supernatural beings
Description: Thank offerings to supernatural being(s)

Name: Pre-battle rituals performed by religious specialists
Description: Offerings, sacrifices, prayers, or other rituals carried out by religious specialists before battle

Name: Post-victory offerings to supernatural beings
Description: Victory offerings made to supernatural being(s) after successful military campaign

Name: Housebuilding offerings or sacrifices
Description: Offerings or sacrifices made in connection with housebuilding or the erection of other structures

Name: Religious pilgrimages
Description: Religious pilgrimages to distant shrines or sacred places

Name: Votive offerings, ceremonies or pilgrimages
Description: Votive offerings or ceremonies or votive pilgrimages made

Name: Idols
Description: Idols: durable representations made in the likeness of supernatural beings through or in which they are worshipped

Name: Oracles
Description: Oracles: shrines, places, or objects where, or by means of which, a medium transmits answers to questions posed to a god or spirit (exclude the use of animals for augury)

Name: Shrines
Description: Shrines, altars, ceremonial platforms, or other sacred places where religious practices (e.g., offerings, rituals, prayers) are regularly or repeatedly carried out

Name: Incense burned for ceremonial or ritual purposes
Description: Incense burned for ceremonial or ritual purposes

Name: Ritual or liturgical texts
Description: Ritual or liturgical (written) texts

Name: Special supernatural practitioners
Description: Special supernatural practitioners (e.g., shamans, diviners, priests, monks)

Name: Religious specialists supported by individuals or society
Description: Religious specialist(s) supported (fully or almost fully) by individuals, the community, tribe, or state

Name: Divination specialists consulted before important undertakings
Description: Specialists (e.g., astrologers) concerned exclusively with divination and related activities (exclude shamans) are consulted before undertakings important to the society or the political leader

Name: Priests
Description: Priests: religious practitioners connected with specific gods or with society-wide ancestral cults

Name: Functionally specialized priests
Description: Functionally specialized priests (e.g., interpreters of oracles or dreams, sacrificial priests, funerary priests, war priests)

Name: Priests formally invested in their office
Description: Priests formally invested in their office by chief, king, or higher priest

Name: Head priest has considerable political influence
Description: Head priest (including priest-chief or priest-king) has considerable political influence

Name: Hierarchy of priests
Description: Hierarchy of priests

Name: Different orders of priests
Description: Different orders of priests

Name: Women consecrated to a temple or a god service
Description: Women consecrated to a temple or to the service of a god (e.g., priestesses, virgins, nuns)

Name: Priests distinguished by visible status marks
Description: Priests or monks always distinguished by specific visible marks of their status (e.g., tonsure, special garments)

Name: Priests follow strict rules of discipline
Description: Priests or monks ordinarily follow strict rules of discipline, including various forms of abnegation (e.g., fasting, continence), purification, or mortification of the flesh

Name: Training school for priests
Description: Training school for priests

Name: Temples
Description: Temple(s): structure(s), at least as large as dwellings, where priests worship gods or practice society-wide ancestral cults

Name: Temple has large staff
Description: Temple has large staff of priests or attendants (more than 10)

Name: Temple owns considerable property
Description: Temple owns considerable property

Name: Temples dedicated to specific gods or saints
Description: Differentiated temples dedicated to specific gods or saints

Name: Monasteries, convents, or nunneries
Description: Monasteries, convents, or nunneries where priests, monks, priestesses, etc., live, and which, unlike temples, are ordinarily closed to laymen

Name: Ceremonial or religious center
Description: Ceremonial or religious center: a complex of temples and associated buildings having an important role in the religious life of the society

Name: Church
Description: Church: religious institution which encompasses a number of priests and temples (or monks and monasteries) and which is unified by a set of common beliefs and observances

Name: Temple or church receives donations
Description: Temple or church receives donations (other than offerings left to supernatural beings)

Name: Temple or church exacts tithes
Description: Temple or church exacts tithes, receives the produce of a fixed portion of cultivated lands, or claims a set part of personal incomes

Name: Church owns large amounts of land
Description: Church owns large amounts of land

Name: Ecclesiastical courts
Description: Ecclesiastical courts

Description: Pottery (either made or commonly used)

Description: Painted pottery made

Description: Large ceramic vessels made expressly for storing or transporting grain or liquids

Description: Mold-made pottery

Description: Wheel-made pottery

Description: Professional (full-time) painters or sculptors

Description: Statues or figurines carved in hard wood or ivory

Description: Stone statues (or figurines) as art or ceremonial objects

Description: Heroic or gigantic stone sculpture

Name: Stone reliefs, intaglios, or friezes
Description: Reliefs, intaglios, or friezes carved into dressed stone surfaces

Description: Murals or frescoes painted on faced stone or brick walls

Description: Glass manufactured

Description: Mosaics of stone, brick, tile, or glass

Description: Ground or polished stone or shell cutting tools

Description: Metal-pointed plowshares

Description: Animal-, wind-, or water-powered devices for grinding grain

Description: Mechanical devices for raising water (e.g., shadoof, water wheel, water screw)

Description: Wheeled vehicles

Description: Scales or balances

Name: Techniques of wood joining
Description: Techniques of wood joining beyond lashing and gluing (e.g., use of pegs, nails, dovetailing, sewing)

Description: Furniture: e.g., stools, benches, platform beds, hammocks

Description: Lock and keys

Description: Mirrors

Description: Plant fibers woven into cloth

Description: Animal fibers (e.g., hair, wool, fur, silk) woven into cloth (exclude unraveling and reweaving of woolen cloth obtained by trade)

Description: Patterns (including warp and weft stripes) woven into cloth

Description: Garments (including capes and cloaks) made of woven cloth

Name: Garments made of bark cloth
Description: Garments made of bark cloth (including ceremonial garments)

Description: Dyeing (not painting or smearing) of textiles, yarn, bark cloth, or pandanus leaves

Description: Fabrics for clothing ornamented with featherwork, elaborate painting, embroidery, jewelry

Description: Tapestries (woven or embroidered fabrics hung for decoration)

Description: Professional weavers

Description: Forging (hammering metal into shape while hot)

Description: Mining of ores (excluding placers)

Description: Mining of ores carried out as a continuing operation (i.e., not merely to meet the needs of the moment)

Description: Smelting of ores

Description: Furnaces for smelting ores

Description: Bellows used in working metal

Description: Indigenous copper worked

Description: Indigenous iron worked

Description: Alloying of metals

Description: Bronze or brass produced

Description: Casting in molds

Description: Lost-wax casting (cire perdue)

Name: Metal hardening through annealing or tempering
Description: Altering the hardness of metals by annealing (heating and slow cooling) or tempering (heating and rapid cooling by immersion in a liquid)

Description: Soldering, welding, or riveting used to join metals

Description: Decorative metal-working techniques (e.g., gilding, embossing, engraving, inlaying)

Description: Bronze or brass weapons, utensils, or instruments in common use

Description: Iron weapons, utensils, or instruments in common use

Description: Non-utllitarian metal objects (e.g., jewelry, figurines or statues, ceremonial chalices, solar disks) made or used

Description: Ornaments and jewelry of gold, silver, or other precious metals made or used

Description: Precious or semiprecious stones used for jewelry

Description: Professional smiths, who work metal primarily for exchange

Name: Professional goldsmiths, silversmiths, or jewelers
Description: Professional goldsmiths, silversmiths, or jewelers

Name: Armorers
Description: Armorers: smiths specializing in making weapons

Name: Watercraft
Description: Watercraft (excluding floating logs and simple rafts)

Name: Vessel hulls built from several planks
Description: Vessel hulls built from several planks (excluding wash strakes)

Description: Vessels propelled by oars (not paddles)

Description: Vessels propelled by sails

Description: Steering oar or rudder
